Manx: AS cre ta gloyr, agh aalid ennym vie,
English: AND what is glory, but the radiance of a name,

Manx: Ennym! ta myr y goll ta sheidey shaghey?
English: A name! which, as a vapour, blows unheeded by ?

Manx: Shoh moylley’n pobble, my she molley shen.
English: This is the people's praise, if praise it be.

Manx: Son cre ta’n pobble, agh jiornage anreaghit,
English: For what is the people? an entangled skein,

Manx: Earroo neuchinjagh, ta son jannoo mooar
English: A fickle mob, who greatly prize

Manx: Jeh nheeghyn eddrym nagh vel toilchin scansh;
As coontey cadjyn reddyn ta feeu arrym.
English: While they condemn what merits veneration.

Manx: T’ad moylley as ta’d ooashlagh shen nagh nhione daue;
English: They praise and they esteem the things they know not

Manx: As shen ta’d gloyragh jiu, ta’d jiooldey mairagh
English: And whom they praise to-day, they blame to-morrow;

Manx: Cha soc eer quo’, agh eer myr tadyr leedit ;
English: They know not whom, but just as they are led;

Manx: Fer er fer geiyrt, myr guoiee trooid doarlish.
English: One following another, as geese through a gap.

Manx: As cre’n cooilleen t’ayns soaigh vooar ny lheid?
English: And what advantage is the esteem of such?

Manx: Dy veaghey er nyn ennal,— goo ny sleih!
English: To live upon their breath,-the people's praise!

Manx: Marvaanee lheaystagh, myr y gheay neuhiggyr!
English: Poor wavering mortals, as the wind inconstant!

Manx: Quoi echey ta resoon veagh blakey lurg oo ?
English: Who is it has reason would be gaping after them ?*

Manx: Lioroo dy ve lheamysit te moylley,

English: By the Rev. ROBERT STEPHEN, Vicar of Marown (1809 to 1827) and of Patrick (1827 to 1842).
THIS IS NOT QUITE A LITERAL TRANSLATION.
